articles.headline: Clear Trend in Pocket Projectors
articles.snippet: The LG, a cellphone with an (almost) built-in projector and the Aaxa, which uses lasers for clearer images, represent a new generation of projectors.
articles.abstract: The LG, a cellphone with an (almost) built-in projector and the Aaxa, which uses lasers for clearer images, represent a new generation of projectors.
articles.lead_paragraph: New technology follows a certain cycle. When a new category bursts out  the VCR, the MP3 player, the netbook  the first models are crude, expensive and underpowered. Several months later, me-too companies rush in, bringing the prices down and the refinement up. A few years later, the VCR, MP3 player or netbook reaches its final form, with only minor refinements in the years to come.

articles.headline: G.M. to Close Hummer After Sale Fails
articles.snippet: A deal to sell Hummer stalled as the companies awaited approval from the Chinese government.
articles.abstract: A deal to sell Hummer stalled as the companies awaited approval from the Chinese government.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  General Motors said on Wednesday that it would shut down Hummer, the brand of big sport utility vehicles that became synonymous with the term gas guzzler, after a deal to sell it to a Chinese manufacturer fell apart.

articles.headline: C.I.A. and Pakistan Work Together, Warily
articles.snippet: As the U.S. war extends deep into Pakistan, the two nations’ intelligence agencies are trying to work together.
articles.abstract: As the U.S. war extends deep into Pakistan, the two nations’ intelligence agencies are trying to work together.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Inside a secret detention center in an industrial pocket of the Pakistani capital called I/9, teams of Pakistani and American spies have kept a watchful eye on a senior Taliban leader captured last month. With the other eye, they watch each other.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: Larger Threat Is Seen in Google Case
articles.snippet: In Italy, three Google executives were held criminally responsible for content posted on the company’s system, suggesting that Google is a content provider that could be regulated.
articles.abstract: In Italy, three Google executives were held criminally responsible for content posted on the company’s system, suggesting that Google is a content provider that could be regulated.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — Three Google executives were convicted of violating Italian privacy laws on Wednesday, the first case to hold the company’s executives criminally responsible for the content posted on its system.

articles.headline: Bribes Let Tomato Vendor Sell Tainted Food
articles.snippet: Prosecutors say SK Foods not only paid off buyers in exchange for contracts but also hid problems like mold.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors say SK Foods not only paid off buyers in exchange for contracts but also hid problems like mold.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert Watson, a top ingredient buyer for Kraft Foods, needed $20,000 to pay his taxes. So he called a broker for a California tomato processor that for years had been paying him bribes to get its products into Kraft’s plants.

articles.headline: At Closing Plant, Ordeal Included Heart Attacks
articles.snippet: A growing body of research suggests job loss can have profound health consequences for workers.
articles.abstract: A growing body of research suggests job loss can have profound health consequences for workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first to have a heart attack was George Kull Jr., 56, a millwright who worked for three decades at the steel mills in Lackawanna, N.Y. Three weeks after learning that his plant was closing, he suddenly collapsed at home.

articles.headline: Banks Bet Greece Defaults on Debt They Helped Hide
articles.snippet: Bets by some of the same banks that helped Greece shroud its mounting debts may actually now be pushing the nation closer to the brink of financial ruin.
articles.abstract: Bets by some of the same banks that helped Greece shroud its mounting debts may actually now be pushing the nation closer to the brink of financial ruin.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bets by some of the same banks that helped Greece shroud its mounting debts may actually now be pushing the nation closer to the brink of financial ruin.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Another Madoff Aide Faces Fraud Charges
articles.snippet: Daniel Bonventre, 63, a former director of operations for Bernard L. Madoff, was arrested and scheduled to appear Thursday in Manhattan federal court.
articles.abstract: Daniel Bonventre, 63, a former director of operations for Bernard L. Madoff, was arrested and scheduled to appear Thursday in Manhattan federal court.
articles.lead_paragraph: A senior executive who worked for Bernard L. Madoff for more than 30 years was arrested Thursday on federal fraud and conspiracy charges, including claims that he had helped Mr. Madoff survive a cash crisis that almost derailed the gigantic Ponzi scheme five years ago.
